awd_titl_txt: Elements: AMR-H: Adaptive multi-resolution high-order solver for multiphase compressible flows on heterogeneous platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
In the past decades, computational research has enabled high-fidelity simulations of complex fluid dynamics problems. However, the new generation of high performance computing architectures present significant challenges in portability and, more importantly, parallel performance of complex science application software. This work develops a multi-purpose computational fluid dynamics solver for high-fidelity high-order adaptive resolution simulations. It leverages the state-of-the-art high performance programming models, Legion and Kokkos, which guarantees the performance portability on various existing and upcoming high performance computing platforms. Additionally, it integrates the commonly used numerical and physical modules, with an easy-to-use programming interface for users. As a significant benefit, the researchers can maintain their focus on physical modeling and not require a deep understanding of code design for new high-performance hardware. The educational and community outreach elements of the project will develop a growing community of computational scientists and engineers who are educated to exploit the power of task-level parallelism and enable a new era in high-fidelity computational science.

This project develops a general computational framework combining high-order, high accuracy, solution-adaptive discretizations of partial differential equations (with emphasis on flows of non-ideal fluids) tailored to the physics they represent. The discretization is optimized for high resolving efficiency, allows optimal use of the computational degrees of freedom and high utilization of the computer resources due to its high arithmetic intensity and data locality. Adaptive mesh refinement in combination with high-order multi-resolution compact scheme allows for easy pre-processing and meshing for complex-geometry problems. Co-designing the numerical framework with new developments in the Legion framework would allow for automated, optimized runtime scheduling of tasks involving computational kernels and data movement across memory hierarchies. This, combined with efficient leveraging of Kokkos, would free the computational scientist/engineer from hardware specific programming models and allow exascale computations on heterogeneous computers. It will enable first of its kind simulations of compressible multiphase flow phenomena in turbulent flow regimes for retrograde fluids on exascale platforms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Elements: AMR-H: Adaptive Multi-resolution High-order Solver forMultiphase Compressible Flows on Heterogeneous Platforms   PI: Prof. Sanjiva K. Lele1,2  Co-PI: Prof. Alex Aiken3  Grant Number: OAC-2103509 Project Manager: Dr. Varun Chandola

Discussions with scientific colleagues involved in high-fidelity computational physics simulations during years 1 and 2 of the current project identified a clear need for an infrastructural tool which would accelerate computational simulations which use compact schemes on HPC systems based on CPUs and/or GPUs. The need for an efficient solver for GPU based systems was particularly stressed.

To respond to these needs we focused the efforts on a linear solver that can utilize the multi-GPU-based high-performance computing resources to solve the tridiagonal and penta-diagonal systems arising from the compact numerical schemes on a 3D computational mesh that is partitioned on distributed memory. Based on this motivation, the linear solver algorithm described in Song et. al (2022) is implemented and shared with the public on GitHub. The software package is named as Compack3D. The release announcement is posted on the website -- https://fpal.stanford.edu/compack3d. Currently, the code is implemented with C++ and CUDA, and support computations on Nvidia GPUs. The implementation based on HIP is under development so that the solver will support computations on broader high-performance computing resources.

A compressible turbulent flow solver based on these communication efficient parallel solution framework was developed, as reported in Song et al (2024) and used for studying turbulence behavior in a wide range of applications from fundamental studies of compressible turbulence, turbulence dynamics in dense gas flows, and transonic shock-buffet in laminar flow control airfoil.

 Currently, the project has gained interest from both academic and industrial research communities, which has resulted in close collaborations with researchers from LLNL, Georgia Tech, NASA and Sandia National Laboratory related to using Compack3D to accelerate their in-house and open-source solvers that utilizes compact finite difference methods for simulations of combustion physics, astrophysics, and compressible flow physics, respectively.

Reference cited above:

Song H., Matsuno, K. V., West, J. R., Subramaniam, A., Ghate, A. S. and Lele, S. K., Scalable parallel linear solver for compact banded systems on heterogeneous architectures, Journal of Computational Physics, Vol. 468, (2022), 111443.  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2022.111443

 Song H., Ghate, A. S., Matsuno, K. V., West, J. R., Subramaniam, A. and Lele, S. K., A robust compact finite difference framework for simulations of compressible turbulent flows, Journal of Computational Physics, Vol. 519, (2024), 113419.  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2024.113419
